Package org.jtrim2.property.swing

Interface SwingPropertySource<ValueType,ListenerType>

Type Parameters:
ValueType - the type of the value of the property
ListenerType - the type of the listener which is notified whenever the value of the property changes
public interface SwingPropertySource<ValueType,ListenerType>
Defines the value of a usual property in Swing. The value of the property may change and client code might be notified of this change via listeners. Listener notification uses the addListener, removeListener idiom.

Thread safety

Adding and removing change listeners must be safe to be called from any thread. However, it is not generally safe to read the value of the property from any thread. In Swing, the usual constraint is that properties might only be accessed from the Event Dispatch Thread.

Similar to PropertySource, listeners might not be notified concurrently.

Regardless of from what thread the property might be accessed, all implementations are required to allow reading the value of the property from a listener. Therefore, if reading a property is allowed from only a particular thread, the listeners must be invoked on that thread as well.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this interface should be synchronization transparent. However, since (usually) there is no documented guarantee for synchronization transparency in Swing properties, one must take care when accessing Swing properties from dangerous contexts (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:

  • SwingProperties.toSwingSource

  • Method Details

    • getValue

      ValueType getValue()
      Retrieves the current value of this property. Implementations of this method should avoid doing any expensive computations or otherwise block.
      Returns:
      the current value of this property. The return value might be null, if the implementation allows null values.

    • addChangeListener

      void addChangeListener(ListenerType listener)
      Registers a listener to be notified after the value of this property changes. In what context the listener is called is implementation dependent but in Swing, it is usually required that listeners be notified on the Event Dispatch Thread.

      Once a listener is notified, it needs to get the current value of this property by calling the getValue() method. Note that, it is allowed for implementations to notify the listener even if the property does not change. Also, implementations may merge listener notifications. That is, if a value is changed multiple times before it is notified, implementations may decide to only notify the listener once.

      Note however, that listeners are not allowed to be called concurrently. That is, listeners registered to a particular property are not allowed to run concurrently with each other.

      Listeners might be unregistered by a subsequent call to removeChangeListener with the listener added. Adding the same listener multiple times will cause the listener to be notified as many times as it has been added. Also, a listener must be removed as many times as it has been added, in order to prevent more change notification. What considered to be the "same" listener is implementation dependent. Equivalence might be based on reference or the equals method.

      Parameters:
      listener - the listener which is to be notified whenever the value of this property changes. What method (and with what argument) is called is implementation dependent. However, most listener types should not have more than one method. This argument can be null, in which case, this method is defined to do nothing.

    • removeChangeListener

      void removeChangeListener(ListenerType listener)
      Removes a previously added listener, so that it is no longer to be notified. Equivalence of listeners might be based on reference or the equals method. If a listener has been added multiple times, it must be removed as many times as it has been added.

      Removing a listener only guarantees, that the listener will eventually be stop receiving more notifications. There is no strong guarantee, that removing a listener will prevent all subsequent listener notifications. That is, for a short period of time, it is possible that the listener will still be notified.

      Parameters:
      listener - the listener no longer needed to be notified. This argument can be null, in which case, this method is defined to do nothing.
